Document 'data/21-29.txt'

Sample Type: Obstetrics / Gynecology

Sample Name: Pre-[Eclampsia] & [Eclampsia]



Description:
A sample note on pre-[eclampsia] & [eclampsia].
(Medical Transcription Sample Report)




PRE-[ECLAMPSIA] is a very serious condition unique to pregnancy i...
[ snip! ]
...s unknown. It is also known as pregnancy-induced [hypertension] or toxemia of pregnancy.

[ECLAMPSIA] is the end-stage of the pre-[eclampsia] process. The vast majority of women who develop pre-[eclampsia] are pregnant with their first child and are towar...
[ snip! ]
... are identifiable risk factors for developing pre-[eclampsia]: family history of pre-[eclampsia], previous pregnancy with pre-[eclampsia], [multiple gestation], and a hydatiform mole (an intrauterine growth th...
[ snip! ]
...ing blood vessel disease increases the risk. Pre-[eclampsia] ranges from mild to severe to [eclampsia] as the end-stage. Untreated pre-[eclampsia] can result in a [stroke], fluid-build up around the lungs, kidney failure,...
[ snip! ]
...d death of mother.

SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS:

MILD PRE-[ECLAMPSIA]:

* Significant blood pressure increase even if ...
[ snip! ]
... protein in the urine.
* Seizures are possible.

[SEVERE PRE-[ECLAMPSIA]]:
* More blood pressure increase.
* Further swelling in face, hands and feet.
* [Visual disturbances].
* [Headache].
* Irritability.
* [Abdominal pain].
* Tiredness.
* Decreased urination.
* Seizures possible.
* [Nausea and vomiting].

[ECLAMPSIA]:
* Symptoms worsen.
* Seizures.
* Muscle twitches.
* [Coma].

TREATMENT:
* Diagnosis - blood tests, urinalys...
[ snip! ]
... office if your headaches become severe, you have [visual disturbances] or if you gain more than 3 pounds in 24 hours.

R...
[ snip! ]
... to consume and look for sodium content.

...he occlusion. The next logical reason would be a [hypercoagulable state]. Some possibilities include [obesity], trauma, surgery, cancer, Factor V Leiden deficie...

[ snip! ]

[ snip! ]

GU: No [urinary hesitancy] or dribbling. No [nocturia] or [urinary frequency]. No abnormal [urethral discharge].
MUSCULOSKELETAL: No myalgias or arthralgias.
NE...
[ snip! ]
...tient denies any rashes or skin changes.

[ snip! ]
...al in cortical echogenicity of solid mass, stone, [hydronephrosis] measuring 9.0 x 2.9 x 4.3 cm. There is a right r...
[ snip! ]

[ snip! ]
...dder is decompressed.

2. No visible renal or ureteral calculi.
3. Right ureteral stent.

Document 'data/23-9.txt'

Sample Type: Ophthalmology

Sample Name: [Cataract]



Description:
A sample note on [Cataract]
(Medical Transcription Sample Report)




[CATARACT] is the loss of transparency of the lens of the ey...
[ snip! ]
... a window that is fogged with steam.

WHAT CAUSES [CATARACT] FORMATION?
* Aging, the most common cause.
* Fa...
[ snip! ]
... exposure to sunlight.

HOW DO I KNOW IF I HAVE A [CATARACT]?
* The best way for early detection is regular e...
[ snip! ]
...are many causes of visual loss in addition to the [cataract] such as problems involving the optic nerve and retina. If these other problems exist, [cataract] removal may not result in the return or improveme...
[ snip! ]
...ision is likely.


DOES IT TAKE A LONG TIME FOR A [CATARACT] TO FORM?
[Cataract] development varies greatly between patients and is affected by the cause of the [cataract]. Generally, cataracts progress gradually over ma...
[ snip! ]
...lly diabetics and younger patients, may find that [cataract] formation progresses rapidly over a few months ma...
[ snip! ]
...ble to know exactly how long it will take for the [cataract] to develop.


WHAT IS THE TREATMENT FOR CATARACTS?
The only way to remove a [cataract] is surgery. If the symptoms are not restricting ...
[ snip! ]
...riate time to do surgery.


WHAT IS INVOLVED WITH [CATARACT] SURGERY?
This surgery is generally performed unde...
[ snip! ]
...ery, a good result cannot be guaranteed.

[ snip! ]
...le ear. Most children will have at least one ear [infection] before the age of four.

...Usually, the presence of fluid results in a "mild [conductive [hearing loss]]." This could be as much as 30% [hearing loss] overall. After the specialist confirms that flui...

[ snip! ]
...are several causes including a viral or bacterial [infection] that spreads to the middle ear by way of the eust...
[ snip! ]
...re. Many factors can increase the risk of an ear [infection] like recent upper respiratory tract illness, crow...
[ snip! ]
...SYMPTOMS:
* Irritability.
* Ear pain, fullness, [hearing loss].
* Infants may pull on ear.
* [Fever].
* Vomiting.
* Discharge from ear.
* [Diarrhea].

* Diagnosis is by physical exam and...
[ snip! ]
...nt to relieve symptoms of upper respiratory tract [infection].
* Antibiotics when indicated for bacterial [infection] such as Amoxicillin or Zithromycin. Finish ALL a...
[ snip! ]
...ven if symptoms subside.

* Avoid swimming until [infection] goes away.
* Surgery is sometimes necessary to p...
[ snip! ]
...e within 2 days of treatment, and for convulsion, [fever], ear swelling, dizziness, twitching facial muscles and severe [headache].
